Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: Ambient energy harvesting technology for IoT wireless sensor applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project will be the development of unique portable energy harvesting and storage technology that can enable ubiquitous deployment of small wireless sensor modules throughout the nation's industrial, civil, agricultural, and institutional infrastructure. The portable power technology developed in this project will enable such devices to be deployed without the need for electrical cables or batteries. This will remove the single biggest technology barrier to growth of the industrial Internet of Things (IoT), namely the difficulty of installing and maintaining large numbers of wireless sensors in locations that need them. Wireless IoT systems, such as for safety monitoring, performance optimization, or predictive maintenance, can significantly increase productivity, efficiency, safety, and cost reduction of operations. This project's developments in electromechanical design, circuit design, and integrated manufacturing will advance the art of ambient energy harvesting technology. These perpetual energy products will help the United States take global leadership in IoT, providing significant economic benefit to the companies that use this technology for their IoT applications. Successful deployment of IoT directly translates into economic growth, increased worker safety, improved environment, and job creation.

The proposed project will develop and manufacture small, inexpensive energy harvesters with built in energy storage for wireless IoT applications. These energy harvesting units will extract energy from ambient sources, such as vibrations, and will provide electrical power for small autonomous IoT devices. The units will feature on-board energy storage, providing power even if the ambient energy source is intermittent or if surge power is temporarily needed. The first units will be optimized for efficiently extracting electrical power from small amplitude vibrations at low frequencies, and can be manufactured at low cost. The same underlying technology can be used to extract energy from other sources, such as air/water flow, mechanical movement, or thermal gradients. The project leverages unique circuit designs and manufacturing processes that enable this unit to be (1) easily integrated into existing electronic systems, (2) efficient in extracting electrical power from low energy sources, and (3) manufacturable at an affordable, market-driven cost. This will result in the development of an extensive product line of small, portable inexhaustible energy sources for wireless IoT.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The result of this SBIR project was the successful development and release of energy harvesting products to perpetually power wireless IoT sensors for industry. Wireless sensors have unique power signatures that put a strain on regular batteries. Unfortunately, current wireless sensors typically have a 1-2 year lifetimes, leading to costly and bothersome battery replacements/maintenance that deem many IoT applications impractical.

 

During the Phase I of this SBIR project, Xidas developed the VEG, capable of generating electrical power from the small vibration frequencies that come off industrial assets (such as machines, motors, blowers, fans, etc), trains, bridges, and more! This commercially viable product hits all major industry-based design criteria: small size, best-in-class power output, and low cost. In Phase II, Xidas finalized the manufacturability of the device and combined the technology with complimentary energy harvesting circuitry and energy storage. In association with the generator, Xidas produced a small, turn-key surface mount module which combines a state-of-the-art power management integrated circuit (PMIC) and supporting circuitry to trickle charge Xidas's RHB-1530 small hybrid supercapacitor/ lithium battery. The all-in-one vibration energy harvesting solution, the VP3, is capable of offering wireless sensors with over 10+ years of life. These products were successfully introduced to the market in Q4 2020, with significant customer traction.

With the majority of sensor applications leveraging vibration being machine condition monitoring, Xidas supplemented the project with a Phase IIB effort to demonstrate the use of these energy harvesting technologies with a wireless predictive maintenance sensor. Through the company?s proprietary micro-engineering and integration paradigm, AMALGA?, Xidas packaged a 3-axis accelerometer, temperature, sound, ultrasound sensor, and a microprocessor all in the size of a dime. Additionally, the company architected an intelligent firmware to be on-boarded on the micro-processor that delivers on-board calibrations, filtering, conditioning, analytics, and trigger alarms based on AI models and pre-set limits. With full autonomy, these smart sensor can operate on their own and provide the cloud with insight as oppose to just raw data. The Phase IIB effort was finalized by combining the predictive maintenance smart sensor with a WiFi transceiver and the vibration energy harvesting technologies. As a result, this product offers industrial end-users with a completely autonomous, fit-and-forget predictive maintenance solution that eradicates all battery replacement and data overload issues. Xidas is now moving forward with pilot production of this solution, with several large industrial players already engaged and committed.
